hero.title: Jani Patrik
hero.subtitle: A Junior Full Stack software developer with a passion for creation who has yet to make a name for himself.

projects.title: Projects & Experience
paragraphs: Throughout my studies and personal initiatives, I have completed several projects where I had the opportunity to work with various frontend and backend technologies. Whether it's websites, admin dashboards, or small games – I always strive to build stable, clean, and well-structured solutions.

Most projects were team-based, where collaborative planning, task distribution, and regular communication played a crucial role. These experiences helped me improve my teamwork skills and taught me how to effectively manage different perspectives.

Every challenge was an opportunity to grow – whether it meant learning new technologies or deepening my existing knowledge. I believe that continuous learning and open-mindedness are key to progress, especially in such a fast-evolving field like software development.

roadmap.title: About me
paragraphs: Hello! I'm a passionate full-stack developer with a love for creating innovative web solutions. My journey in programming started in 2019, and since then I've been constantly learning and growing in this exciting field.

I specialize in modern web technologies including React, Node.js, and database management. I'm always excited to take on new challenges and collaborate on interesting projects that make a real impact.
roadmap.subtitle: My Journey

experiences.title: Started Coding
content: I began learning the basics of programming and built my very first application — a simple calculator in C#, following a video tutorial.
This small project helped me truly understand how coding works, such as using variables and performing calculations.

experiences.title: First Grade in High School
content: I successfully started my first year in high school, where I began learning programming in a more serious way, not just as a hobby.

I explored basic structures like classes, loops, functions, and scopes. Most of my work at the time was in Python, which I found quite frustrating — and to this day, I still don’t really enjoy using it. :D

experiences.title: Vocational Basic Exam
content: I passed my Vocational Basic Exam with flying colors, achieving a 99% result.
I had studied hard for the exam, but lost 1% on the interactive section due to a few mistakes. Fortunately, I earned a perfect score on the practical section, which made the effort worthwhile.

experiences.title: Attended Prograce
content: Prograce is a nationwide coding competition held in Pécs, and I was fortunate to participate in it.
It was my first real coding competition, where I had the chance to meet many talented students from other high schools and universities.
The challenge was in Scratch, which made it a fun starting point. Although we didn’t make it to the podium, the experience was incredibly valuable.

experiences.title: Returned to Prograce
content: Two years later, I returned to Prograce, once again in Pécs, but this time the competition had a much more serious atmosphere.
There were around 100 participants, including university students, and the event lasted the entire day.
The challenge was in Java — my first time working with the language. Despite the steep learning curve, my team successfully earned fifth place, which was a huge accomplishment.

experiences.title: Pollak Bell
content: In my final year of school, I worked on my thesis project with two teammates. We named it Pollak Bell.

It was a full-stack web application built with Vue for the frontend and a NestJS backend written in TypeScript. For database management, we used PostgreSQL, running in Docker and Docker Compose as our containerization tools.
The application was actually used in our school by over 100 students, making it my first large-scale, production-level project.
